Hudson City School District voters approved the $50,684,738 budget for the 2020-21 school year with 1,267 in favor and 748 opposed. The proposition to establish a capital reserve fund was also approved with 1,338 in favor and 676 opposed.

In the Board of Education election, incumbents Sage Carter and Carrie Otty were re-elected to three-year terms ending in 2023, receiving 1,574 votes and 1,623 votes, respectively.

Thank you to everyone who voted! This was the highest voter turnout in recent history and we appreciate the time and effort you put into casting your votes via absentee ballot. We hope you all come back to the polls next year!

The Scrub Club at HHS participated in a brief “Stop the Bleed” training with one of our School Resource Officers, Deputy Sohotra.

The goal of the training was to show students how they can prevent traumatic bleeding during emergencies such as natural disasters and auto accidents. It can take up to 15 minutes or more for first responders to arrive, especially in rural areas, so knowing how to best apply pressure and how to correctly use a tourniquet can be life-saving in some cases.

Deputy Sohotra and Scrub Club advisor, Mrs. Forsyth, demonstrated the proper use of a tourniquet before the students got to practice on each other.

post_text: Thank you to Petty Officer James Willis from the U.S. Navy for talking to students about real-world applications of what they’re learning in school! He shared many insights about nuclear power and renewable energy, which are topics covered in Chemistry and AP Environmental Science at HHS. In addition to discussing the benefits of nuclear power, Mr. Willis discussed how power is collected from the fission process, fission vs. fusion, basic construction and operation of a reactor, as well as the hazards and risks associated with radiation exposure. He ended his presentation by discussing potential job opportunities related to nuclear energy within the military and private sectors.

post_text: 5th graders learned all about Australia in preparation of a visit from HHS Class of 1987 alum, Robert Unson, who is currently a hotel manager in Melbourne, Australia. The visitors brought their own photos and stories to share with the class, as well as fake Australian currency and tasty Australian treats called Tim Tam. Many thanks to Robert and his friend Juan, a South African native who moved to Australia as a child, for visiting Mrs. Curry’s class!

It is with great honor that Dr. Antonio W. Abitabile, Principal of Hudson Senior High School, announces that eleven seniors and 2019 graduates have been recognized as AP Scholars. To receive this honor, students must achieve grades of 3.0 or higher on at least three full-year AP (Advanced Placement) Exams.

Congratulations to Spencer Goldstien, Autumn Kudlack, Sarah Li, Rowan Meyers, Majed Murshed, Emilia Ortiz, Katarina Scali, Ahsraful Shamrat, Kyle Ublacker, Michael Zhang, and Victoria Gardner (who was named AP Scholar with Honors, which means she earned a minimum of 3.25 on AP exams and scored a 3 or more on at least 4 of those exams!).

We are both proud and saddened to announce that Dr. Abitabile will be leaving the district in late December after accepting a position as Superintendent of Schools at the Lansingburgh Central School District. Dr. A has aspired to become a superintendent and this is an exciting opportunity for him and his family. He will still be with us for half the school year and will assist in the leadership transition process. We are thankful for Dr. A’s leadership at HHS and the many things he has helped us accomplish over his 17 years in our district. We are sad to see him go, however we look forward to welcoming a new principal who will continue to expand opportunities for our students. We wish him the best of luck in his new position!

Visit our website for more info on the position and the link to apply: www.hudsoncityschooldistrict.com/employment
